title: The Hebrew Pharaohs of Egypt (gnv64)
description:
The Hebrew Pharaohs of Egypt: The Secret Lineage of the Patriarch Joseph
by Ahmed Osman
Bear & Company | September 2003 | ISBN-10: 1591430224 | PDF | 208 pages | 19.6 mb <a href="
http://www.amazon.com/The-Hebrew-Pharaohs-Egypt-Patriarch/dp/1591430224" rel="nofollow" target="_NEW">
http://www.amazon.com/The-Hebrew-Pharaohs-Egypt-Patriarch/dp/1591430224</a>

A reinterpretation of Egyptian and biblical history that shows the Patriarch Joseph and Yuya, a vizier of the eighteenth dynasty king Tuthmosis IV, to be the same person

Ã¢â‚¬Â¢ Uses detailed evidence from Egyptian, biblical, and Koranic sources to place Exodus in the time of Ramses I
Ã¢â‚¬Â¢ Sheds new light on the mysterious and sudden rise of monotheism under YuyaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s daughter, Queen Tiye, and her son Akhnaten

When Joseph revealed his identity to his kinsmen who had sold him into slavery, he told them that God had made him Ã¢â‚¬Å“a father to Pharaoh.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ Throughout the long history of ancient Egypt, only one man is known to have been given the title Ã¢â‚¬Å“a father to PharaohÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½--Yuya, a vizier of the eighteenth dynasty king Tuthmosis IV. Yuya has long intrigued Egyptologists because he was buried in the Valley of Kings even though he was not a member of the Royal House. His extraordinarily well-preserved mummy has a strong Semitic appearance, which suggests he was not of Egyptian blood, and many aspects of his burial have been shown to be contrary to Egyptian custom.

As The Hebrew Pharohs of Egypt shows, the idea that Joseph and Yuya may be one and the same person sheds a whole new light on the sudden rise of monotheism in Egypt, spearheaded by Queen Tiye and her son Akhnaten. It would clearly explain the deliberate obliteration of references to the Ã¢â‚¬Å“hereticÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ king and his successors by the last eighteenth dynasty pharaoh, Horemheb, whom the author believes was the oppressor king in the Book of Exodus. The author also draws on a wealth of detailed evidence from Egyptian, biblical, and Koranic sources to place the time of the departure of the Hebrews from Egypt during the short reign of Ramses I, the first king of the nineteenth dynasty.

About the Author
AHMED OSMAN was born in Cairo in 1934 to Egyptian Muslim parents. He studied law at Cairo University and later worked as a journalist and playwright. Since 1965 he has lived in England. This project is the culmination of twenty-two years of writing and research. Osman is also the author of Moses and Akhenaten and Out of Egypt.
